text: I think the built-in set module should do the trick.

code:
>>> elements = [range(100)[::4], range(100)[::3], range(100)[::2], range(100)[::1]]
>>> sets = map(set, elements)
>>> result = list(reduce(lambda x, y: x & y, sets))
>>> print result
[0, 96, 36, 72, 12, 48, 84, 24, 60]

text: Use sets, which have an intersection method.

code:
>>> s = set()
>>> s.add(4)
>>> s.add(5)
>>> s
set([4, 5])
>>> t = set([2, 4, 9])
>>> s.intersection(t)
set([4])

>>> data = [range(100)[::4], range(100)[::3], range(100)[::2], range(100)[::1]]
>>> sets = map(set, data)
>>> print set.intersection(*sets)
set([0, 96, 36, 72, 12, 48, 84, 24, 60])

text: Convert them to sets and use the set.intersection method, reducing over the list of sets:

code:
xs = [range(100)[::4], range(100)[::3], range(100)[::2], range(100)[::1]]
reduce(set.intersection, [set(x) for x in xs])

text: reduce is a functional programming device that iterates through any iterable and applies the function provided to the first two elements, then to the result and the next, and then the result of that and the next, and so on.
I'm going to answer my own question:

code:
lists =  [range(100)[::4],range(100)[::3],range(100)[::2],range(100)[::1]]

out = set(lists[0])
for l in lists[1:]:
    out = set(l).intersection(out)

print out

text: You can treat them as sets and use set.intersection():

code:
lists = [range(100)[::4], range(100)[::3], range(100)[::2], range(100)[::1]]
sets = [set(l) for l in lists]

isect = reduce(lambda x,y: x.intersection(y), sets)

l = [range(100)[::4], range(100)[::3], range(100)[::2], range(100)[::1]]
l = [set(i) for i in l]
intersect = l[0].intersection(l[1])
for i in l[2:]:
    intersect = intersect.intersection(i)
